body:
Also those really infatuated with the classic UI always have the option to
stick to the previous version for a bit longer. +1 on making Lens default.

also they can mount the web assets on a proxy and still benefit from the
core changes. remember the classic UI only uses the rest api and
config.json there's no buddy or anything.
Let me look into adding the i18n stuff to lens

I'm no longer helping with this pull request. I've asked many times to keep the change contained to rabbitmq, and to continue looking at this work displaces time from other things.

someone else can help ask you to revert the other changes and the mysql change you recently introduced. Otherwise, we should close this PR

to whoever, if anyone, continues this.

new features need explanation, justification and relevance. As we've noted on our README, mysql is not a production setup, so we should not be adding awkward new flags like isAsync to it.

Focusing on the change here, we should have the same rigor as looking at change like the elasticsearch shard settings.. ask "when would a user override prefetch?" "what's the side effect of acking, particuarly on error vs not at all?" "Is this acking similar to other collectors such as SQS?"

Because the shared understanding will help with this, especially if the next version of the driver changes the behaviour. Ideally someone is able to confirm the intent is actually useful, who has RMQ experience vs me reading docs etc. But for me, I've failed to even coerce this change to become contained. Anyway, this is my 2p for the next person, if there is one.

For now, I'm ignoring this issue as it is irritating to continue to ask for the same thing and yet it not occur.

Manual ACK with prefetch count setting on a channel prevents RabbitMQ broker from flooding the consumer with messages. These settings will not make any difference if you are acknowledging messages that are't completely processed. Non blocking span storage does not make sense for collectors like RabbitMQ, because it is processing messages of a queue. Span sender isn't waiting for any response.

Solution that I proposed in this pull request did resolve the performance issue in our environment.

Anyway, thank you for your time. I'm closing the pull request.
FYI I offer to add documentation in release notes about nginx with classic. sure. still would be archived, which can formalize that we aren't doing security patch management on it, etc.
Ah I was expecting the release notes for this repo when updating - `zipkin-classic` doesn't need any more work other than archival
LGTM! Cheers to the classic UI, it was fun while it lasted, long live Lens! üçª üçæ üéâ

Hello,
@adriancole I'm up for this issue.
Could you please assign me to it or tell how to become a contributor?
Thank you in advance,

Thanks @aerfus and good luck. You can raise a pull request using the normal github flow. Ex fork this project, make a branch for the work. look at the lens readme so you can verify. You can also look at existing similar unit tests. Once works, you can raise a pull request based on your branch. https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin for questions. If you stop working on this, just comment back so that it doesn't block others. Take care and see you around.

This is an exception after requesting the webpage. Do you know how to solve it??

2020-02-06 14:21:54.094 [armeria-common-blocking-tasks-1-9023] WARN  zipkin2.server.internal.BodyIsExceptionMessage - Unexpected error handling request.
com.linecorp.armeria.common.ClosedSessionException: null
@peacejj this is usually when there is a connection or latency problem. please use gitter for troubleshooting https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
@peacejj this is usually when there is a connection or latency problem. please use gitter for troubleshooting https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
@uckyk 40000 is way too many span names. please use gitter for troubleshooting https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
Came here to say that I would also like this feature (to not force lowercase names). @adriancole is there any chance we could reopen this and gauge how much interest there is? Thanks

interest is one thing, interest in doing the work to accomplish it.. that's the limiting factor. no one I know has several months free time with the only gain being case preservation.

All the work to redo schemas of cassandra indexing to somehow support mixed case search, case deduplication in keyspaces etc, and then transition folks with migration plans.. this is a huge order to place on someone.

Remember tag values can be preserved and span names are usually derived from tags. Practical options are sometimes better than moving huge boulders up a hill.

ps it isn't just cassandra either, elasticsearch is similar. the span name would be greatly effected in terms of size and performance if switched from keyword to case insensitive. also, we'd open the possibility of bad search results coming back, resulting in client-side deduping on the UI.

It is a tall order, and I'd really recommend using tags as that has no change in the model. For example, we have site-specific tag support in the search and UI and the values there can be mixed case. They appear same as name in the UI controls.

Perhaps we could make this configurable with a simple boolean flag so that people who intend to use a backend that already supports case preservation can use it, and the rest of the community can continue to use the auto-lowercasing behavior.

(My actual use case: I'm using Spring Cloud Sleuth + Brave to report traces to LightStep using Zipkin reporting, and would like to preserve the case of span names and operation names for readability. Most names use PascalCase and this is not something that I can easily change organization-wide.)

@csabakos brave doesn't lowercase anything except when converting to Zipkin model. I've not seen the Lightstep integration, but there's no reason it has to convert to zipkin model which does the lowercasing. Literally the FinishedSpanHandler was made for rendering data differently for non-zipkin destinations. Please chat on gitter if you want more info as I think the topic isn't related to this thread now that you mention the use case. https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

as mentioned in chat, the boolean flag would be hard to pass and awkward on
a value type. Also, we'd be making our code intentionally incompliant with
our own spec which has been stable for ages. Finally an issue doesn't need
to be re-opened in order to have people vote for it.

the only reason I am asked specifically is usually people expect me
personally to do the work. I personally won't be doing this work. I can say
that for sure.

Anyone else can do this if they accept the responsibility that comes along
with it. This issue is about the full-scope feature of case insensitive
data, not the special case of reporting, though.

Since the reporting use-case is specific to Brave, which doesn't even
depend on code in this repo! I moved the issue about this here
https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/issues/1077

A smaller scope issue is easier for volunteers to pick up, if lightstep are
unable to implement a FinishedSpanHandler to do this on their own. Hope
this helps!

I'm looking at this issue. I know in #1946 we added a mechanism for injecting the base path from the server to read in the client. But wondering, does anyone remember if there was any gotcha from just trying to extract the base path from the current `window.location`?

I think a URL that renders zipkin-lens can only look like one of these patterns
- https://fooserver.com/mysite/myzipkin/
- https://fooserver.com/mysite/myzipkin/dependency
- https://fooserver.com/mysite/myzipkin/traces/39048234098234
- https://fooserver.com/mysite/myzipkin/traceViewer

So simple processing of `window.location.href` can find that the base path is `https://fooserver.com/mysite/myzipkin/`

One corner case is if a user enters there own 404 URL like this
- https://fooserver.com/mysite/myzipkin/foobar/

With just parsing of the URL, we would end up treating this as a base path (the URL to the discover page) of `https://fooserver.com/mysite/myzipkin/foobar/`. Ideally, the reverse proxy itself throw the 404 for this, but in case it doesn't, we'd still be able to do it though if we treat a 404 for `BASE_PATH/config.json` as a 404 page. This doesn't seem too high priority to me though since we're already not very good, lens displays a blank confusing page if a request of an unknown path does make it through (e.g., when using the dev server) so any handling of bad URLs would be an improvement regardless of base path handling.

Interpreting the base path would allow users to proxy without even worrying about setting a property. And it simplifies our dev server too by removing the dev-only `API_BASE` environment variable.

Let me know if you have any concerns about such an approach. /cc @abesto

I don't think there was any gotcha before, tho we did not use react (it was
not a SPA either) so it is worth to keep an eye on it (are we using
react-router?).

Any thoughts on this @pchiwan? (Resolving basepath from window.location vs
setting one on beforehand)

Where @llinder @zeagord and I ended up was that we needed a way to choose which trace IDs would be associated with a period represented by a dependency link. Otherwise, you have to store rows for every pair related to that link. In other words, the bounds force you to choose somehow and we stopped at that.

What happened since, was some backends have the ability to store the metric rows associated with a link, for example https://github.com/jeqo/zipkin-storage-kafka or the https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-voltdb. This means that at query time, you could choose exemplars which are more representative and not as biased as trying to do that on each host prior to reporting.

## Aside as link picking is not that much different than normal time series picking:

Long long ago, the first version of zipkin had favorite functionality. This was basically manual picking which could be arbitrary or to mark something exemplary. We've had a ton of various thought works happening around this topic since, and in many areas. Below is only a survey of the first that come to mind.

I think Jaana actually started the fire on people wanting to use exemplars also for arbitrary metric points https://medium.com/observability/want-to-debug-latency-7aa48ecbe8f7

One idea we had in micrometer support was to do try to keep a configuration which could decide what is exemplary and use evaluate local histograms towards that. Lacking that, we could certainly just pick randomly rate-limited.

Later, we learned about haystack, which punts all the way down the line, and use a decoration service: adaptive alerting. In other words, they don't pretend to know what's exemplary up-front. Instead, they use some sort of model selection to do that and update your exemplar store somehow.

Last year, someone told me excitedly about their zipkin exemplar integration.. It looked basically the same as Jaana's pictures. Grafana with zipkin trace exemplars co-plotted. However, it took significant hacking due to the lack of integration in grafana etc. Here, we discussed with LINE the same topic and resolved to park the grafana idea as their api was supposed to change dramatically to formally support things without massive hacks.

All this said, I noticed some projects are picking up similar work again, ex [jaeger exemplar support](https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger-lib/pull/79), I figured I'd recap where we got on links and picking favorites has significant overlap with doing the same for arbitrary metrics derived spans and picking favorites (exemplars).

hope this helps any lurkers or anyone here that wants to try again.

I think this is a problem with the discover page not trace page.
So I think we can solve this issue only by change the following Box which has onClick callback to anchor tag.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/956cdd5cd2f9b4f649c6fecd645e3fe52964244a/zipkin-lens/src/components/DiscoverPage/TracesTab/TracesTableRow.jsx#L106
cc @drolando

Hi, nara. The span is and has always been intentionally immutable. Can you use another type for mutable changes? like Brave's MutableSpan? or a normal pojo? I can help with a json codec if it helps you..

I think we had an old issue about collector-side mutations, and agree that the span type isn't efficient. Just I don't think retroactively a make Span mutable is the answer. Doesn't mean we can't make another option.. worst case we add a version of MutableSpan here... @jeqo thoughts?
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2807 should be updated based on this discussion and work
@drolando if you have a chance to try this, would be best!
`MutableSpan` is helpful also. JSON codec is necessary to be able to create this type from the data published by the tracers. This is not a critical ask, just a nice to have for us.
Thanks @tacigar! awesome

Just a thought, is it possible to use the proto? Protos are also immutable but conversion to builder is shallow so usually is pretty fast. Though perhaps not fast enough - wondering if it could work though.
netflix pipeline is in json format, so for this use case probably isn't that useful even if they were ok adding the chain of deps for google's proto plus json.

@narayaruna in case it works for you, I think what rag might be suggesting is to use our backported proto def https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-api/blob/master/zipkin-jsonv2.proto and generate the json stuff from that, which would match the same model as zipkin2.Span

worth thinking about it, as it kicks the can further down and might buy time depending on urgency.

Yeah was hoping one or the other :) Also shameful plug for fast proto - json 

https://github.com/curioswitch/curiostack/blob/master/common/grpc/protobuf-jackson/README.md

https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-security is a more complete example of how someone can bolt-on HTTP security features available in Armeria. Note: this is still not warrantied for reasons mentioned and that Armeria isn't v1.0 yet either

noticed some feedback about the amount of links being perhaps excessive https://twitter.com/Monkeyanator/status/1236069513701085184

If we consider design impact of removing them.. if it weren't for the links, we could have the entire bottom of the layout dedicated to presenting actual stuff..
also in hind sight I'm not sure how many have come to gitter due to the links in lens.. we have no analytics to suggest if they are helping or not.

Hi. we ask folks to start with gitter for support. you might notice this in
the issue template. that's because there tends to be situations where
troubleshooting doesnt result in a change to code in this repository.

can you switch your example to use the zipkin v2 json endpoint instead of
thrift and carry on with gitter? also make sure latest zipkin and py_zipkin

https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

FWIW the do_stuff spans look very incorrect as they are showing as client
and also server spans. do_stuff seems to be something that should be a
local span (no kind set)

please follow up on gitter but this might need to escalate to py_zipkin if
after you change to not using thrift it is still bad.

I would just keep the gitter one with a icon of help or just don't add any
icon at all (just keep the language one).

cc @openzipkin/core as I think everyone should know that `$PWD/zipkin-server.properties` is magically read. When folks insist on properties files, this should allow a consistent answer, while simultaneously transferring support burden to those who choose to do that.

I can understand feedback about the number of links or the current design of displaying them. I still would argue at least a link back to the open source project/community should be somewhere, as it is for other open source monitoring tools. Otherwise users within a company may think Zipkin is a company tool (especially if integrated into an internal tool) or the only route to feedback/contribution is the operator within their company, which they may never know who that is. Giving a path directly to us encourages engagement and proper attribution/recognition of the project. I'm no designer but would be happy to review alternate designs.

Latest heading rewords things to hopefully avoid custom servers. I'd forgotten we firstly called Zipkin a Spring Boot server, which perhaps led to people thinking they can just customize it. While we do rely on Spring boot, most things we do are custom or Armeria specific. cc @trustin @minwoox
Yeah don't have to but figured it's a good chance to

My personal opinion is a single link to the home page. Gives a pointer to the open source without being too direct to chat. I think it would be great to have an awesome conversation start because of the gitter link in the UI but I there's at least as good a chance that all parties involved would prefer going through the zipkin operator who will be able to answer e.g., "Why don't traces show up" by first checking if their storage is down.

Of course we could just wait and see if this is actually a problem or not.

Another thought is keep the help icon defaulted to gitter but add a knob to configure it so users can link to internal jira or something. This would just be a few lines of code but seems pretty useful for operators.
